 THE FEDERAL DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF ETHIOPIA ETHIOPIAN SOCIAL REHABILITATION AND DEVELOPMENT FUND PROJECT 1. ECONOMIC OVERVIEW A. GENERAL ECONOMIC SITUATION IN ETHIOPIA 1.1 Country Background. Ethiopia is one of the poorest countries in the world, with a population of over 50 million people and an average per capita income of US$ 130. Ethiopia's economic status is reflected in the poor condition of the productive sectors, neglected or non-existent infrastructure, degraded environment, and very poor social indicators and basic services. Agricultural growth declined from an average of 2.2 percent a year during the 1960s to 0.5 percent in the 1980s and the early 1990s. The 6 million hectare under cultivation has hardly increased since the early 1980s. Only about 2 percent of farm land is irrigated. Agriculture supports about 85 percent of the population, but its contribution to GDP has dropped from 65 percent in 1960, to about 40 percent today. The industrial sector has also stagnated under the previous regime because of excessive public sector domination and discouragement of private sector activity, and accounts for only 10-12 percent of GDP today. 1.2 Ethiopia's infrastructure is undeveloped, and has deteriorated significantly due to lack of maintenance during the last twenty years. The country's road density is one of the lowest in Africa (only 15.2 km per 1000 square km, and only 4000 km of paved roads). Nearly three quarters of the country's farms are more than half-a-day's walk from all weather roads; and 65 percent of the road network is classified as poor due to inadequate maintenance, war damage, and overloading. This adds substantially to vehicle damage and transport costs. Limited energy capacity is also a major constraint to development. 1.3 Ethiopia's population growth rate of over 3 percent has resulted in heavy pressure on many areas, resulting in severe environmental damage through stripping of forests for fuelwood and poor farming and conservation practices. About 200,000 ha are deforested each year. At current rates of soil loss, the areas unable to sustain crops could grow five- fold in twenty years, reducing by 15 percent the capacity of land to support its current population, reducing incomes by 30 percent in areas with few economic alternatives. 1.4 The Government's Economic Reforms. In May 1991, the Transitional Government (TGE) inherited a devastated economy and massive debt from the military dictatorship that ruled Ethiopia for two decades. The TGE introduced an Emergency Recovery and Reconstruction Program (ERRP) to jump-start the economy with US$ 650 million support from an IDA-led donor group. Accompanying this was a program of macroeconomic reform which has helped stabilize the economy, dismantle the centrally planned system of the previous regime, restore Ethiopia's competitive position through a substantial exchange rate devaluation, and open opportunities for private investment. The industrial and service sectors responded strongly with growth of 7.6 percent and 9.6 percent respectively in FY94. Given the economy's heavy reliance on agriculture, the FY94 drought reduced GDP growth from 12 percent the previous year to 1.7 percent. In
 2 FY95, the rate of growth was restored to about 5 percent, and is expected to exceed 6 percent for FY96. Prudent financial management has resulted in greater control over inflation and the fiscal deficit, although the increase in economic activities is placing pressures on both. An increase in government spending between FY93 and FY95, from 23.2 to 26.4 percent of GDP, was financed mostly by revenue increases resulting from improved coffee exports, and the fiscal deficit1 decreased from 7.1 to 3 percent of GDP. The Government is also paying off its debt to domestic banks. Inflation was substantially reduced from 36 percent in 1991, and is estimated to be running at the equivalent of an annual rate of 13.4 percent, buoyed by foreign exchange inflows and domestic monetary expansion. 1.5 The Government has enacted structural reforms to stimulate investment, trade, and production. Exports have been boosted by eliminating all export taxes (except on coffee) and reducing license fees. All retail prices have been decontrolled, except for pharmaceuticals and petroleum. The top import duty was lowered from 230 to 60 percent, and the negative import list abolished. The introduction of an auction system has improved foreign exchange availability and narrowed the auction and parallel rates to less than 10 percent. State monopolies in freight forwarding, marketing, and export activities have been abolished, and the banking system opened to domestic private participation. The 1992 Investment Code introduced new investor incentives, and the Government has embarked on a privatization program under an autonomous Privatization Agency. 1.6 Macroeconomic and structural reforms have been accompanied by a substantial restructuring of public expenditures, shifting resources from defense to social services and roads. Education's share of the budget increased from 7.1 percent in FY89 to 13.4 percent in FY95, and that of health increased from 2.8 percent to 5.4 percent. Allocations to roads increased from 3 percent to 14 percent over the same period. B. PATTERNS AND SOURCES OF POVERTY IN ETHIOPIA 1.7 Social Indicators and Social Services. Ethiopia's poverty is revealed by the country's social standards. Life expectancy is just 48 years, 117 per thousand infants die within the first year, as do twenty percent of children under five. Almost 700 women die in childbirth for every 100,000 births. More than 70 percent of the country is susceptible to malaria, and tuberculosis is the major cause of hospital registered deaths. 1.8 Five factors contribute to Ethiopia's poor social conditions. Thefirst is over- crowded housing which spreads communicable diseases. The second is lack of safe water, producing high rates of diarrhea and schistosomiasis. Only 17 percent of the country has access to safe water, compared to the Sub-Saharan African average of 41 percent. Almost 94 percent of the rural population use untreated water from rivers, lakes, and wells. Almost 40 percent of urban dwellers and most rural households have no sanitation facilities. The third factor is inadequate nutrition and poor infant feeding practices, worsened by chronic diarrhea. The daily per capita calorie intake in Ethiopia is 1 After grants, on a cash basis.

Between 7 and 10 percent of Ethiopian children are moderately to severely wasted, and between 40 and 60 percent of children under five are both stunted and wasted. Micro-nutrient deficiencies contribute to high levels of goiter, anemia, and rickets. About 1.5 percent of the population is blind due to vitamin A deficiency, and about 26 percent suffer from iodine deficiency. Thefourth factor is the low education and literacy, which results in high fertility rates, poor maternal and infant health, and poor nutrition practices. 1.9 Thefifth factor is the poor condition of Ethiopia's basic social services. Only 55 percent of Ethiopian families live within 10 kilometers of a health facility, and only 10 percent of children under five receive modern health care. Compared to generally accepted guidelines, Ethiopia's health stations have to serve twice as many people as they should (about 23,000 each), and health centers three times as many (about 317,000 each). Despite recent improvements, immunization rates are still well below Sub-Saharan African norms, and less than 25 percent of births are attended. Ethiopia has the lowest primary education enrollments in Sub-Saharan Africa, only 22 percent, with 16 percent fewer girls than boys enrolled. Recent declines in enrollments are due to a combination of war damage to about 1,160 primary schools (about 15 percent of the total); the low ratio of properly trained teachers; very high drop-out rates (47 percent between grade I and grade 2); and poor quality of education. 1.10 Chronic Poverty. Ethiopia's chronic poverty is the result of high population growth rate and poor economic performance. From 1981 to 1991, population grew at almost 3 percent a year, economic growth averaged only 1.7 percent a year, and growth in agriculture averaged only 0.9 percent a year. Poor economic growth is the result of policy distortions under the previous regime; intermittent droughts endangering 7 million people; loss of productive land due to environmental degradation; low use of agricultural technology; constraints on internal trade due to transport difficulties and state marketing monopolies; over-dependence on a small range of exports; domestic conflict and insecurity; low rates of investment and savings; and a low level of external development assistance ($15 per capita a year compared to Sub-Saharan Africa's average of $34). In the decade 1978/9 to 1988/9, per capita food grain production dropped from 200 kg per person to about 150 kg per person, matched by increased food imports from 178,200 tons to 1,460,400 tons, 70 percent as relief assistance. 1.11 The World Bank's "Ethiopia- Food Security Study" (June 1992) estimated that there are (i) 19 million rural resource poor reliant on farming but unable to obtain sufficient food for the household due to inadequate land, livestock, poor climatic conditions or soil fertility; (ii) 750,000 poor rural resettlers, inadequately resettled and experiencing significant hardship trying to live by farming; (iii) 400,000 urban poor, chronically under-nourished, many in women-headed families, spending 85 percent of their low income on food; and (iv) 230,000 urban unemployable with no family support- structures, unable to work because of age, disability, or mental illness. 1.12 Transitory Poverty. Transitory poverty in Ethiopia is the result of war, forced resettlement, and drought. There are four main categories of transitory poor: (i) rural pastoralists in drought prone areas, who have lost their traditional livelihood and coping
 4 mechanisms; (ii) groups affected by the war, over two million refugees and persons displaced within Ethiopia, households suffering dramatic family losses, the disabled, farmers whose means of livelihood was destroyed, and demobilized soldiers; (iii) over half million rural refugees from Sudan and Somalia; and (iv) urban dwellers vulnerable to policy reform, especially public sector employees being retrenched. 1.13 Distribution of Poverty. The TGE' 1992 Social Dimensions of Adjustment Study classifies almost 52 percent of Ethiopian households as very poor, chronically poor, vulnerable, or susceptible nomadic groups. In some areas, the percentage of poor households exceeds 70 percent and in the worst cases is as high as 85 percent, with more than 50 percent of households in the extremely poor category. In the areas in which poverty is especially acute, there is a severe lack of basic social services, acute lack of access to safe water supply, and primary school enrollments as low as 7.1 percent, compared to the national enrollment average of 22 percent. 2. CONTEXT FOR THE PROJECT 2.1 The proposed Project will be an expansion of the pilot Ethiopian Social Rehabilitation Fund (ESRF) to all parts of Ethiopia. This section provides the context in the form of (i) the development and sector strategies for Ethiopia; (ii) the experience of the pilot ESRF; and (iii) lessons from other social fund operations. A. DEVELOPMENT AND SECTOR STRATEGIES FOR ETHIOPIA 2.2 Ethiopia's Development Strategy. Sustained poverty reduction is the main goal of the Government's development strategy, to be achieved through a combination of sustainable economic growth, improvements in basic social services, and specially targeted measures to improve incomes, self reliance, and the quality of life of the poorest groups and communities. Drawing on the Bank report "Ethiopia: Toward Poverty Alleviation and a Social Action Program (1993)", the aim is to strengthen the capacity of the rural population to cope with periodic droughts, and provide food security. Economic growth will be the basis for poverty reduction through increased employment and incomes, higher food production, and export foreign exchange earnings. The economic growth program has four elements. The first is to maintain macroeconomic stability, by reducing the budget deficit and domestic bank financing of the deficit, controlling inflation, and keeping the foreign exchange rate competitive and interest rates positive. The second is to stimulate production through the strategy of Agricultural-Development- Led Industrialization (ADLI), which will balance the importance of agriculture as a source of income and food, with the sector's limitations in providing employment for Ethiopia's rapidly growing population, by increasing output in three areas: (i) in agriculture through improved small-holder productivity, and expansion of larger farms, especially in the lowlands; (ii) in the industrial and service sectors through improved productivity; and (iii) in the production of minerals to diversify Ethiopia's exports. The third is encouraging investment through private sector growth, streamlining procedures governing investment and trade, and liberalizing the financial sector. The fourth is improving infrastructure, services, and natural resource management, through focused
 5 ;nvestments essential to sustained growth, especially in roads, electricity, agricultural services and credit, and environmental rehabilitation. Sectoral Strategies 2.3 This section will summarize the Government's sector strategies related to poverty reduction most directly concerned with community-based programs and the proposed ESRDF Project. 2.4 Improving Social Services. A priority goal is to strengthen the social sectors, to reduce the population growth rate and improve productivity and employment opportunities of the poor, through better basic health, education, safe water and sanitation, and nutrition. This program will need to correct regional and urban-rural imbalances, improve services to women and children, and encourage a wider range of public and private service providers. Between FY91 and FY95, military spending reduced from 24.6 percent 13.4 percent of the budget, and allocations for education and health increased from 7.1 percent to 13.4 percent, and 2.8 percent to 5.4 percent, respectively. 2.5 Basic Education. The GOE's goal is to expand primary education, and technical and vocational training; make access to secondary education more selective and competitive; and improve the internal efficiencies cf the educational system. Primary education will provide a basis of mathematics and science, promote practical problem- solving aimed at future schooling and employment, and increase awareness of the physical and social environment. At the primary level, both English and local languages will be used as media of instruction. Strong emphasis will be given to community involvement in building, rehabilitating, and maintaining primary schools, and in participating in basic education management. Efforts are being made to improve the training of teachers, upgrade educational materials, strengthen National Regional Government of primary and secondary schools, and correct gender and regional imbalances. 2.6 Basic Health and Nutrition. Most of the increased resources for health will go to the primary facilities and services, increases in essential drugs and supplies, and more and better rural health workers. The goal is to reduce maternal and child morbidity and mortality, combat communicable diseases by improved immunization, control diarrhea, improve treatment of respiratory diseases, strengthen antenatal care and delivery services, and promote nutrition programs linked to MCH. The short term priority is rehabilitating war-damaged facilities, especially health clinics at the woreda level, each to be headed by a health officer trained to diploma standard. These clinics will provide curative and rehabilitative health care and family health services; educate and mcbilize communities to improve environmental health conditions (digging latrines, maintaining water facilities, and clearing malarial swamps); and encourage community investment in construction, and participation in asset management and maintenance. Actions have also been taken to establish the new structure of health services at the woreda, zonal, and regional levels.
 6 2.7 Population Management. Reducing the growth in population is essential for capturing the poverty reduction benefits of economic growth. The GOE aims to reduce current high fertility rates from an average of 7.7 children per woman to 4 children, by 2015. This will be achieved through a significant increase in contraception use; lower maternal, infant, and child mortality; increase in girls education and women's literacy; programs to increase women's income and economic participation; and information programs promoting smaller family size. A National Population Council has been established to coordinate this multi-sectoral program, supported by regional and zonal population councils and woreda committees. 2.8 Rural Water Supply and Urban Sanitation. Because of the prevalence of diseases related to contaminated water and poor waste disposal, better rural domestic water supply and urban sanitation is a major prerequisite for improving the health of poor households. The inadequate state of rural water supply in Ethiopia is both a reflection and cause of the country's poverty. Only 19 percent of the rural population have access to organized water supply, and as schemes are often out of commission actual coverage is about ten percent. In some regions, rural communities have almost no access to safe water. Domestic investment in rural water supply has declined recently with donors and NGOs providing the bulk of the financing. The Government's proposed National Rural Water Supply Program (NRWSP) envisages expenditures of US$ 303 million in 13,390 schemes by 1998, but this program is yet to be fully financed. With limited resources and a huge demand, the Governmnent faces a dilemma in balancing new construction with maintenance and rehabilitation. Currently 83 percent of resources go to new construction, and 17 percent to rehabilitation. GOE policy is to promote simple, low-cost technology (hand-dug wells and handpumps) for small communities with the principle of covering maintenance costs through user fees. Institutional strengthening will be a major priority, involving a more rational distribution of responsibility for rural water management among regional authorities, ensuring that each region has adequate organizational structures, and building effective linkages among regions and between regional bureaus and the central ministry. 2.9 The GOE also gives high priority to improving urban environmental conditions, especially sanitation, as part of its program to upgrade the health of the urban poor. The approach is to provide urban communities with financial and technical assistance and incentives to invest in and manage their own sanitation facilities. The environmental aspects related to improved water and sanitation services, particularly disposal of solid waste, drainage and refuse disposal, are key concerns in the GOE's National Conservation Strategy. The contributions of the ESRF pilot and expanded ESRDF are part of a broader effort to improve urban sanitation, which includes the IDA-financed Second Addis Urban Development Project, the Ethiopia Water Supply Development & Rehabilitation Project to be proposed for IDA financing, and the UNDP-World Bank Water & Sanitation Program. The ESRDF will focus on community initiated and managed schemes, mainly in Addis Ababa and Harrar, two cities that have the status of regions and are therefore included in this otherwise rural program. 2.10 Small-Scale Irrigation. The ADLI strategy aims to increase agricultural output and rural employment and incomes, by boosting the productivity of small-holder farmers,
 7 and diversifying crops to increase the value of exports and reduce fluctuations in production. Irrigation will be the primary vehicle for overcoming the formidable constraints of unpredictable rainfall patterns and insufficient soil moisture for the productive use of modem inputs. The GOE's strategy distinguishes three kinds of irrigation schemes. Individual small-scale irrigation schemes cover up to 200 ha, and usually consist of diversions from small rivers, springs, or micro-dams to individual farmer plots. Medium-scale irrigation schemes, often owned by farmer cooperatives, cover areas of between 200 and 1000 ha and generally rely on medium-sized dams or diversion methods. Large-scale irrigation schemes are concentrated mainly on state farms, and utilize major diversions normally requiring pumping. The GOE gives strong emphasis to small-scale irrigation schemes, and envisages more than doubling the 160,000 ha of land currently under irrigation, utilizing the considerable supply of largely untapped ground and surface water in some of the country's major river basins. The importance of new and rehabilitated small-scale irrigation schemes are reflected in allocated expenditures for the period up to 1996. 2.11 Programs Targeted at Poor Groups. To supplement measures aimed at economic growth, the GOE has launched programs aimed at specially disadvantaged groups. These include rehabilitation programs for over half a million refugees returning from Somalia, Sudan, and Djibouti; credit and retraining programs for retrenched public employees; credit and rehabilitation programs for 500,000 demobilized soldiers; consumption programs for 25,000 highly vulnerable households; cash assistance to 160,000 of the poorest rural households to purchase fertilizer, seeds, tools, and veterinary drugs; food/cash-for-work public works programs to improve infrastructure in 15 cities; essential agricultural inputs for 150,000 displaced people resettled on farms in Tigray, Amhara, Oromiya, and SEPRA; urban food and health umbrella programs for slum dwellers in Addis Ababa; and cooperative programs with World Food Program and UNICEF for destitute farmers and women, and the unemployed. 2.12 Regionalization and Community-Based Development. The most important political events influencing the development program has been the devolution of significant authority and responsibility to the administrations of the newly established regions whose status has been confirmed in the December 1994 Constitution for the Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia. In addition to a range of governmental powers, devolution includes a transfer to National Regional Governments of responsibility for development planning and project implementation, within the budget allocations and broad sectoral policies established by central ministries. The goal of this process is to give Ethiopia's various nationalities far greater control over their own political affairs, and economic and social development. This trend goes hand-in-hand with the goal of increasing the capacity and self-reliance of local communities, encouraging them to take responsibility for their own development through community planning and project committees. These projects will involve community contributions to project and recurrent costs, the use of labor-intensive methods, and the choice of simple technologies that communities can maintain. The goal is to utilize this mechanism to deliver small-scale projects that communities can manage themselves, focusing on improving community health, nutrition, education, and family planning through better basic social infrastructure and services; and providing the essential infrastructure (feeder roads, irrigation schemes,
 8 marketing centers, grain storage, rural power) and training required to stimulate economic activities and increase incomes. This process will be supported by intensive training of communities, local NGOs, local small private contractors, and other facilitators of community-based development. The ESRF pilot has been a major initiative within this program. 2.13 Strategies for the Advancement of Women. The Government places great importance on removing the constraints on women's economic and social participation, and encouraging their progress. The new constitution guarantees to women the right to acquire, manage, and transfer land and property; gives women fundamental social rights; and protects women from traditional harmful practices. Development strategies, especially at the community level strongly emphasize women's participation in planning and implementation; giving women literacy and basic skills to engage in economic activities; facilitating access to savings services and credit for income generation activities; and supplying simple technologies (such as grain mills and oil seed presses) that can help reduce the burden of women's work. Sectoral programs, generally implemented through community participation, will have a major impact on improving women's economic and social status, especially primary education which will help a whole new generation of girls. MCH programs will preserve the health of mothers and their infants. Water supply programs will ensure accessible safe water, saving hours spent by women carrying water from distant and often contaminated sources. 2.14 Strategy for Environmental Conservation and Rehabilitation. The GOE's National Conservation Strategy (NCS) articulates the policies, strategies, actions, and investment program needed to address the main environmental problems confronting Ethiopia. Under the NCS, each National Regional Government is responsible for formulating regional conservation strategies based on the NCS guiding principles. The NCS is comprehensive and multi-sectoral in scope, highlighting the need to (i) limit land degradation and loss of tree cover; (ii) respond to the insufficient supply and poor quality of water resources; (iii) manage the increasingly serious effects of urban degradation; (iv) contain the progressive loss of bio-diversity; and (v) reduce the damage done by poor management methods on the ecological stability of rangelands and the livelihood of the traditional rangeland populations. The NCS stresses the need for environmental objectives in all sector strategies, programs and projects dealing with agriculture, energy, roads, water supply, industry, and urban development. Finally, the NCS emphasizes the importance of giving communities a stake in conservation and rehabilitation, through providing environmental education, the right incentives, stress on environmental criteria in community-led project implementation, and methods that the community can readily use to preserve their natural resources. 2.15 World Bank Country Assistance Strategy (CAS) for Ethiopia. The Bank's CAS for Ethiopia supports the Government's program to promote employment- generating economic growth as the long-term foundation for poverty reduction. The CAS includes assistance with a policy framework to stimulate production, exports, and private sector development; measures to reduce population growth and develop human capital; improvement and expansion of essential infrastructure; environmental rehabilitation and conservation; and institutional capacity building for economic growth and social
 9 development. The proposed ESRDF Project is a central element of the CAS. It translates into practice a number of important CAS principles: improving project implementation by building capacity at a regional level; focusing directly on poverty reduction methods, including labor-intensive activity, basic services and infrastructure for poor rural communities, improving incomes and food security; increasing the economic and social participation of women; and encouraging community concern for environmental conservation and rehabilitation. The proposed Project will also contribute to key sectoral goals emphasized in the CAS: support to small-holder farmers through irrigation schemes; expansion and rehabilitation of rural water supply and urban sanitation; improvements in basic health services for the poor; expansion of primary education with a focus on increasing girls' participation; and support to community-based initiatives aimed at improving essential infrastructure and stimulating incomes, especially for poor women. B. THE EXPERIENCE OF THE PILOT SOCIAL REHABILITATION FUND 2.16 The Selection of a Social Fund Mechanism. The pilot ESRF began in December 1992 as a component of the Ethiopian Recovery and Rehabilitation Program (ERRP). The aim was to test whether a social fund approach could be an effective way of giving millions of poor households and communities in one of the world's poorest countries, greater control over their economic and social advancement, a goal that could not be achieved by central public agencies alone. The devolution of accountability implied by a social fund approach coincided with the decision to regionalize political authority. 2.17 The challenge of the ESRF was to see whether the pilot could match the features of the most successful social funds, which have been able to make a distinct contribution within the range of development approaches. They can provide a parallel track to the conventional public-sector planning cycle (which inevitably creates queuing problems) by allowing a community with energy and commitment to launch initiatives within its own time-frame. Social funds can be an effective way of encouraging private efforts which can often deliver more cost-effective results than the public sector alone. They can be an effective way of attracting community investment, which reduces the cost to public funds and establishes a basis for ownership around which maintenance arrangements can be built. The mechanism more readily permits multi-sectoral integration than projects designed and managed by public sector agencies. Social funds can also contribute to community-based development by building local management skills, encouraging community decision-making on joint assets, and developing a sense of achievement and self-reliance. 2.18 Summary of the Pilot Fund Experience. The US$ 13 million ESRF pilot has been operating in Southern Shoa, Addis Ababa, and Tigray, with 10 percent of its financing available for other regions. Its goal has been to provide financial and technical support for small community-initiated projects, in which communities invest at least 10 percent, and carry contractual responsibility for management and subsequent maintenance. ESRF was launched through a promotional campaign to inform communities about the Fund's facilities and procedures, identify community needs, and
 10 provide basic training in identifying and submitting sub-project proposals. The pilot encouraged management by community committees, and fostered linkages between communities and local support groups, local government officials, community facilitators, NGOs, and private contractors. Within a general sub-project limit of US$ 250,000, the Fund is open to any initiatives with a positive developmental benefit for the community. In practice, the pilot has focused on support for (i) the rehabilitation or building of basic health facilities, primary schools, micro-dams, feeder roads, water supply and sanitation facilities; (ii) programs in adult skills development and literacy training; and (iii) support for income-generating ventures carried out by small groups, often consisting of women. ESRF was launched with a modest administrative structure, and has operated with an overhead of less than 5 percent of total project cost, which is efficient by social fund standards, and compares very favorably with the public sector costs of delivering project services. 2.19 Results to Date. At December 30, 1995, 1,026 proposals had been received, of which 462 were regarded as priorities and suitable for appraisal. Subsequently, 67 were returned to applicants for reformulation, 170 failed to meet ESRDF appraisal standards, and 225 were approved for financing. Six were later canceled due to legal requirements and performance failure of implementing agencies, and another nine delayed. In total, the ESRF had completed 219 sub-projects by December 30, 1995. Some 564 suitable proposals have been placed in the pipeline for consideration by the follow-up ESRDF program. Evaluation of ESRF Performance 2.20 Community Participation. ESRF's performance has been measured through an independent evaluation after eighteen months operation, a mid-term review in October 1994, and 6 supervision missions. The evaluation's independent engineers confirmed that the infrastructure built with ESRF support satisfied national sector standards and has been of good quality. There is also evidence that the ESRF has been successful in generating community commitment and helping build community leadership. The 2.1 million people benefiting from the ESRF pilot consist of those in the poorest and most vulnerable categories: primary schooling for over 20,000 children from poor families; training for almost 390,000 adult illiterates and destitute ex-soldiers; basic health services for 329,000 inhabitants of poor villages; latrines for over 230,000 people, and improved drainage for a further 75,000 people in the poorest sections of Addis Ababa; rehabilitated feeder roads linking poor communities to markets and other essential facilities, benefiting over 780,000 villagers; measures to help the productivity of poor peasant farmers: irrigation and micro-dam storage for over 1 1,000, storage facilities benefiting 145,000, and conservation measures benefiting almost 44,000; and income generation schemes reaching almost 15,000 people belonging to vulnerable groups (destitute ex-soldiers, women heads of household, displaced civilians, poor peasants, and orphans). While it is too early for a definitive study on the sustainability of assets created with ESRF support, the evidence is that many requirements for future sustainability are in place. For water supply schemes, they operate as Water Committees, setting water tariffs and collecting user fees. The collected money, used for maintenance and repairs, has so far been sufficient. Completed small-scale irrigation sub- projects are managed by Water Users' Committees with their own by-laws and regulations, assisted by Ministry of Agriculture extension workers. Users contribute from the sale of produce to maintenance and repair costs. Maintenance of public latrines is managed by beneficiary families and supervised by the kebele administration, which collects user fees and provides keys to door locks that limit access to members. 2.26 Identified Problems and Solutions. One of the most important reasons for the pilot's success was the responsiveness of Fund staff to community needs. Hlowever, the ESRF's thin structure was often stretched to its limits and its work schedule delayed. Sometimes Fund staff had to provide extensive assistance to bring community proposals to an acceptable level for consideration. In many rural areas there was a shortage of local contractors with the financial resources to purchase construction materials and facilities
 13 to transport the materials to remote sites. ESRF could often purchase construction materials more cheaply from central stocks, and transport it more efficiently using its own facilities. In such cases, ESRF took on procurement responsibility, leaving the local project committees to deal with labor contracts. The formula worked effectively but produced a heavy workload for the Fund. The proposed solution to this problem, incorporated in the design for the expanded ESRDF, is a comprehensive capacity building program to (i) prepare the Fund for its expanded role; (ii) respond to the weaknesses among bureau staff, NGOs, local contractors; and (iii) provide communities with skills to manage their own initiatives by training community project committees, and strengthen links between communities and local facilitating groups. The Fund is recruiting high quality staff for the expanded phase, supplemented with more use of short-term consultants for technical studies and specialized supervision. The Fund will use sub-contracts with specialized institutions or NGOs in providing training and technical support to community organizations and local bureaus. Action will also be taken to improve the incentive structure for Fund staff, given that some excellent staff were attracted away by higher NGO and international agency salaries. 2.27 The evaluation found that many income-generating proposals received by ESRF were of too low a standard for consideration, demonstrating the need for ESRF to expand its research and educational role in this area. ESRF also experienced difficulties coping with the work-load generated by the banking aspects of income-generating operations. In the future, the Government will support the development of savings and credit intermediary organizations, village banks, at the community level. 2.28 Finally, while it was found that ESRF was committed to maximizing benefits to poor women and responding to environmental concerns, establishing specific functional responsibilities in the ESRF would improve the attention given to both themes. It was also agreed to include more specific gender and environmental criteria for sub-project identification, appraisal, monitoring, and evaluation. 2.29 Additional Regional Studies. LESSONS FROM OTHER SOCIAL FUND OPERATIONS 2.30 In addition to the pilot experience, the design of the ESRDF has been based on the lessons from some 30 other social funds and social programs the Bank is financing mainly in Latin America and Africa. UNDP, the Inter-American Development Bank, and the African Development Bank are also supporting social funds. Like most social funds, the ESRDF will operate as a semi-autonomous financial and administrative agency, reporting to a high level and visible Board, separate from but collaborating with the civil service. Like other funds, the ESRDF will have an incentive structure aimed at attracting and retaining high quality staff. In line with the findings of the Africa Technical Department's study "Social Action Programs and Social Funds, A Review of Design and Implementation in Sub-Saharan Africa" (June 1993), the ESRDF will carry out extensive
 14 community promotion to ensure that proposals are genuinely beneficiary initiated; operate with a high degree of autonomy; ensure high standards through rigorous appraisal; and work with flexible financing, procurement and disbursement processes to encourage community participation in implementation. Most ESRDF financing is likely to go to the type of small infrastructure projects shown by social fund experience to be most successful in terms of quality and sustainability, and their contribution to community efforts to increase incomes and improve their quality of life. Social funds operate with an administrative overhead cost of between 5 and 15 percent of overall project costs. The ESRF was able to operate at the low end of this range and although the ESRDF's overhead expenses will be higher than the pilot phase, because of the remoteness and limited capacities of some regions, these expenses will still remain at the low end of the range. Overhead costs will be reviewed each year as part of the process of approving the annual operating budgets. 2.31 The ESRDF will also follow other important lessons from social fund experience: (i) operating as an action-research program with close monitoring, feedback learning loops, and adjustment to varying circumstances; (ii) focusing on building the capacity of local community leaders and facilitators to ensure ownership and high quality community participation; (iii) using well-tested, simple, and labor-intensive technologies; (iv) being managed as an integral part of a broader poverty reduction strategy. B. PROJECT OBJECTIVES 3.2 The expanded Ethiopian Social Rehabilitation and Development Fund (ESRDF) will provide to poor, mainly rural communities the assets and services needed to improve their economic and social standards. ESRDF will provide financial and technical support to communities and community groups to construct or rehabilitate, and maintain basic
 15 economic and social infrastructure and services that they have prioritized and in which they are willing to invest. In addition, ESRDF will support community actions aimed at environmental conservation and rehabilitation. ESRDF's efforts will be focused on poor communities, and especially, poor women. To achieve these goals, ESRDF will strengthen community capacity in project identification, implementation, and maintenance. The Fund will support only sustainable, cost effective developmental initiatives, and will not be involved in relief activities. 3.3 The Project will also support the establishment of a Welfare Monitoring System to strengthen capacity to collect and analyze information related to causes, patterns, and incidence of poverty; and improve the basis for developing poverty reduction strategies, assessing the impact on the poor of economic policy reform, and evaluating the benefits of other poverty reductions interventions. C. PROJECT DESCRIPTION 1. Roles and Responsibilities in the ESRDF Program 3.4 Communities. ESRDF will be a demand-based program, and will finance only sub-projects that are community-initiated and suitable for community management. For each sub-project, the benefiting group or community will form a Community Project Committee (CPC) which will participate actively in identifying, preparing, appraising and implementing sub-projects, and will be a party to all contractual arrangements with the Fund. The CPC is also responsible for collecting community contributions (not less than 10 percent in cash, kind or labor) to the capital costs of the sub-project, and for managing the maintenance of facilities through user fees, and other community contributions. 3.5 ESRDF. ESRDF is responsible for promoting the Fund among communities and National Regional Governments; and for appraising sub-project proposals received from communities to ensure that they are cost effective ways of improving community assets and social conditions, are developmental and sustainable in nature, and are environmentally sound. Once a decision is taken to finance a sub-project, the ESRDF monitors and supervises implementation, and ensures a proper hand-over of completed facilities to Community Project Committees. ESRDF is also responsible for monitoring and reporting on all Fund activities. 3.6 Facilitators. Communities will be able to obtain support from a wide range of facilitators that will collaborate with ESRDF, including NGOs, regional sector bureau specialists, private contractors, and specially trained community facilitators. 3.7 National Regional Governments. Regional sector bureaus will be responsible for ensuring that the sub-projects satisfy sector policies and standards; for committing budget resources for recurrent costs that are government responsibility; and for providing ESRDF technical support in sub-project design, appraisal, and implementation.

The ESRDF Central Office will plan and manage financial transfers, and monitor and evaluate project implementation. Regional Steering Committees will approve sub-projects and ensure that the Regional Offices, which receive, process and recommend community applications for ESRDF support, operate in accordance with the Operational Manual. 3.9 ESRDF Board. The Board, chaired by the Prime Minister or representative, consists of the Head of the Regional Affairs Bureau, the Minister of Finance, the Minister of Economic Development and Cooperation, The Minister of Water Resources, and the Minister of Agriculture. The Board is responsible for ensuring consistency with ESRDF policies and the procedures of the Operational Manual, for approving the annual budget and work program, for approving the progress report, and for appointing the external auditor of the Fund's operations. 3.10 ESRDF Central Office. The Central Office is headed by a General Manager who will keep the Board informed on key issues relating to ESRDF's operations. The Office is responsible for (i) ensuring that ESRDF operates according to Operational Manual; (ii) preparing annually for the Board and IDA a review of ESRDF performance (including a financial report), and a consolidated work program and budget based on the pipeline of proposals received by Regional Offices; (iii) supervising and monitoring the activities of Regional Offices; (iv) replenishing regional accounts on receipt of specified financial records and supporting documentation; (v) managing all international procurement for ESRDF; (vi) managing the project performance monitoring and information system; (vii) managing the capacity building, training, and research program and providing technical support to regional offices; (viii) proposing policy changes to the Board; and (ix) representing ESRDF in all legal matters. The Chairperson of the National Regional Council, or representative, chairs the Committee consisting of the Heads of the Social Development Sector, the Economic Development Sector, the Planning and Economic Development Bureau, and the Finance Bureau; and representatives of the Commercial Bank of Ethiopia or the Development Bank of Ethiopia, and representatives of civic organizations. The Manager of the ESRDF Regional Office, appointed by the Chairperson of the National Regional Council, is a member of the Committee and act as its secretary. 3.12 Regional Offices. The Central and Regional Offices are already operation, and are staffed with technical specialists, generally qualified engineers, in the main areas of ESRDF's project business, and specialists to manage the Fund's administrative, accounting, monitoring, and capacity building functions. The Manual will be supplemented by Handbooks on Small-Scale Irrigation; Social Sectors; Rural Water Supply and Urban Sanitation; Promotion and Training; and MIS operation. Cross-cutting themes like gender and environment will be included in each Handbook. Handbooks will include project design, appraisal, and implementation guidelines; national and regional technical standards and specifications; training materials for building the capacity of community committees, practitioners, and implementors; and the organizational accountability and framework for supervision, quality control, and post-completion maintenance. The Handbooks are being prepared by the Central Office in coordination with Regional Offices, taking account of the socio- economic features of each region, and highlighting mechanisms to promote community participation. While some Handbooks will be ready earlier, all Handbooks will be ready before the end of the first year ofproject implementation. 3.16 Promotional Phase. ESRDF will start operations in new districts with a program to promote the objectives of ESRDF among communities, explain its operating
 18 mechanisms and benefits, describe its experience with other communities, and discuss links between ESRDF-financed activities and other development initiatives. This will be followed by a participative review of the community's overall needs and priorities, and ways in which Fund can assist. Fund staff will assess the capacity of the community to identify needs, prepare and submit proposals, and manage implementation and asset maintenance. Some initial training may be offered, or plans made to provide training later. They will also discuss the possibility of local facilitators to provide assistance. For those wishing to submit a proposal for ESRDF support, Fund staff will help communities establish Community Project Committees to take leadership of the process. During promotional visits, the ESRDF will present its particular mandate within the context of overall community needs to improve basic social standards and facilities, improve incomes, conserve environmental assets, and attend to the needs of special groups such as poor women. 3.17 Screening and Appraising Proposals. Communities may submit proposals to the ESRDF Regional Office directly or with the help of a facilitating intermediary or NGO. Proposals can be sent by a Community Project Committee, a local association (such as a farmers' group), or a cooperating set of individuals (such as a women's group or parents' committee). The Regional Office screens proposals to determine whether they fall within ESRDF's business mandate, are relevant to the needs and priorities of the community, are the result of community initiative, are presented in a complete enough form, and appear feasible. Proposals that fail to satisfy ESRDF standards and criteria will be rejected, although ESRDF will arrange for assistance to improve proposals that show promise but are in some way defective. After the preliminary screening, a formal appraisal will be done by an ESRDF Project Officer in coordination with the regional sector bureau concerned, and based on criteria and standard formats included in the Operational Manual. The criteria include: (i) suitability of the sub-project to community management and maintenance; (ii) the realism of sub-project costs in line with standard costs for the sector; (iii) the tangibility and importance of anticipated benefits to the community, and the cost benefit (including calculation of an economic rate of return); (iv) the cost effectiveness based on the number of beneficiaries reached and consideration of least-cost alternatives; (v) satisfaction of national and regional sector technical standards and plans; (vi) arrangements for the community's investment of at least 10 percent of sub-project costs (in the form of cash, materials, labor, or other services); (vii) the adequacy of arrangements for management of implementation and maintenance, and coverage of recurrent costs; (viii) responsiveness to the needs of women and other special groups; (ix) satisfaction of environmental standards defined in the Operational Manual; and (x) the clarity of indicators for sub-project monitoring and evaluation. 3.18 Project Approval, Financing Agreements, and Implementation. Successfully appraised sub-projects will be submitted by the Regional Office to the Regional Steering Committee for approval. If approved, the Regional Office will sign a Financing Agreement with the Community Project Committee (and with any intermediary acting on behalf of communities) specifying the goals of the sub-project, accountability and liability, project costs, details of the community contribution, implementation, procurement and supervision arrangements, disbursement procedures, special actions needed to mitigate any negative environmental effects, and follow-up arrangements for
 19 maintenance and recurrent costs. Where, as in the case of health facilities and schools, the sub-project involves recurrent costs for maintenance and operation for which the regional bureau is responsible, the ESRDF will finance the sub-project only once the National Regional Government has agreed to take on and budget for this responsibility. Agreements will be required on the community's responsibility for maintenance and recurrent costs of water-supply, sanitation, and small-scale irrigation schemes. Examples of the Financing Agreements are contained in the Operational Manual. 3.19 Implementation arrangements will be kept flexible to reflect very different conditions among the regions in terms of availability of services, markets, and local contractors. However, the general principles that will guide implementation will be to (i) maximize community involvement and responsibility; (ii) ensure adequate quality; and (iii) ensure the most cost-effective methods through competitive bidding. Where small-scale irrigation schemes have been successful, they have provided many rural communities with a valuable, albeit limited, input for local food supplies and livestock management. These schemes in Ethiopia are essentially community based. To provide water security in an equitable manner, cultivators are allocated a small parcel of irrigated land to supplement their traditional production from rain-fed crops and animal husbandry. During and after the rains, irrigation is used to secure and enhance production of field crops. In the dry season, the emphasis is on mixed horticultural crops. Storage dams are also important in providing water for livestock during drought conditions. Although there are abundant water resources in Ethiopia, their harnessing and utilization is costly owing to the seasonal characteristics of stream flow. Economy of water development will be a key aspect of ESRDF support for small-scale irrigation schemes. During the life of the Project, cost comparisons will be made between ground water utilization and the cost effectiveness of schemes relying on surface water. Initially, the ESRDF will promote the use of traditional and well-tried technologies suited to local management and operation, and the limited maintenance resources available under prevailing conditions. Over time, however, ESRDF will encourage efficiency in the management of the irrigation system through research and into improved modern methodologies now finding their way into developing countries. A key appraisal priority will be to match the investment in water catchment or storage facilities with the economic returns likely to result from cultivation. Therefore, a careful assessment will be made of the land to be cultivated through irrigation to determine fertility, crop choice and suitability, siting, and long-term sustainability. ESRDF will support the efforts of the agricultural bureaus and extension workers to train farmers in irrigated farming methods, and in the maintenance of water catchment infrastructure and irrigation schemes. In its appraisal of small-scale irrigation sub-projects, the ESRDF will take account of the community's access to the essential agricultural inputs needed to ensure that the full potential of the investment is captured. F. THE DEVELOPMENT SIGNIFICANCE OF THE ESRDF 3.53 ESRDF has been designed to fit the development realities of Ethiopia. Sustainable economic growth will lay the foundation for long term poverty reduction. This needs to be complemented by actions that will enable millions of poor people in isolated rural communities to take advantage of the benefits that economic growth can bring. Such benefits could pass them by unless there are significant improvements in their standards of health, education, and their access to water, a scarce and vital asset for domestic and farming use. The escape from poverty will also depend on the capacity for households to increase their meager incomes. Some will be able to do so through improved farming methods utilizing water provided by small-scale irrigation schemes supported by careful conservation of natural resources. However, because of significant land-population pressure in the poorest areas of the country and the high cost of expanding land under c.Altivation, many others will need to rely on off-farm employment. These priorities are the main-stream of ESRDF business, and the Project is a central part of the poverty reduction strategy. 3.54 Ethiopia's commitment to regional devolution will bring development decisions closer to communities and increase their responsibility for the development process itself: the identification of priorities, the design and management of interventions, and the maintenance of assets. The ESRDF has been designed to utilize the new regional institutional structures, to stimulate the participation of beneficiary communities (in terms of investment, management, and responsibility for sustainability), to strengthen working relationships among governmental bodies, NGOs, and private sector contractors, and to build the capacities of all involved in this participative developmental approach. 3.55 ESRDF Compared to Other Options. The ESRF was piloted to determine whether a specialized financing agency could jump-start the process of participative community-based development to empower local communities right from the outset, and to compensate for the inevitable length of time that it will take to strengthen weak regional institutions. In addition to testing whether the mechanism would work (respond to beneficiary-initiated proposals and deliver the priority infrastructure and services required), it was also important to ensure that the Fund could do so at acceptable costs and levels of effectiveness and efficiency. Through the pilot, the Fund has demonstrated its capacity to foster and respond to community-led efforts, and to deliver good quality infrastructure and services with significant community investment, at lower costs and
 32 more efficiently than could be done by public agencies. To some extent, this is a reflection of the careful limits placed on the ESRF's activities. The Fund operates with small projects that are suited to community participation, using simple technologies and established sectoral standards. Any experimental or risky ventures are introduced strictly on a pilot basis so that they can be closely monitored. The work load of the Fund is also carefully attuned to the delivery capacity of Fund offices, especially the work load of Project Officers. (Calculations based on the pilot experience are contained in the Project File). The ESRDF is therefore not a replacement for larger-scale public agency responsibility for delivering sector programs. It is an essential complement, because while the Fund ensures that sector standards are respected, it can respond rapidly and flexibly to community initiatives. Its streamlined structure and operating procedures, financing mechanism independent of the civil service budget, ease of operation across sectors, and planning process based upon a pipeline of community proposals, gives the Fund some special advantages over public agencies, and well placed to work directly with beneficiaries. Without the Project, many ESRDF objectives could be achieved through public programs, but at much higher cost and over a longer time frame. This would especially disadvantage thousands of poor communities in some of the poorest parts of the country, where it will take time to build effective regional public institutions. The unique contribution of ESRDF is its ability to work closely and respond rapidly to poor communities, and to mobilize the contributions of specialists from the public, private and NGO sectors to build the capacity needed for participative poverty reduction efforts.  Annex B Page 1 of 6 National Poverty Reduction Strategy A. Introduction I. The reduction of poverty is a central goal of the Government's Economic Development Strategy for Ethiopia. The roots of Ethiopia's extensive poverty are deep and complex, and reducing poverty will require a range of mutually reinforcing measures at a number of different levels. Shaping out this strategy depend, therefore, on a sound understanding of the nature and causes of poverty in Ethiopia. 2. Although poverty in Ethiopia takes many forms, it is important to differentiate between transitory poverty and chronic poverty. Transitory poverty is the result of the dislocation caused by years of protracted war and policy actions by the previous regime, that resulted in displacement and separation of hundreds of thousands of people from their social and economic sources of support. In this category there are refugees returning from the bordering countries to which they fled to escape war and persecution, families uprooted by the previous government's forced resettlement policies, people displaced as a result of losing their means of livelihood (especially rural populations that fled to the cities), demobilized former soldiers, workers retrenched from overstaffed public agencies, orphans and the disabled. Special, targeted programs will help reintegrate many of these transitory poor back into community settings and a means of economic and social support. Some proportion will fail to reintegrate and will swell the numbers of the chronically poor. 3. It is estimated that well over half of the population of Ethiopia are chronically poor, and millions of others are vulnerable, through shocks such as droughts and environmental damage, to joining the chronically poor. Although this form of poverty exists in urban areas, the cities have borne the brunt of transitory poverty problems, and chronic poverty is chiefly a rural phenomenon in Ethiopia, and especially severe in some parts of the country. From a macro- economic viewpoint, chronic poverty in Ethiopia is fairly readily understandable. Due to a combination of misconceived policies, massive wastage of national resources diverted into war, significant neglect of some regions of the country, and recurring climatic disasters, the Ethiopian economy has stagnated and declined at the same time that the population has been increasing at about three percent a year. 4. The results of this general economic situation can be seen in the poorly developed and neglected state of the country's essential infrastructure, the lack of basic social services and access to safe water, some of the worst health indicators (in terms of child and maternal mortality, disease, and malnutrition) in Africa, and severe and increasing environmental degradation in areas where population pressure has taken its toll on limited land resources. About 85 percent of the population earn their living from agricultural activities, but due to neglect of the sector, the contribution of agriculture to GDP has declined from 65 percent in 1960 to about 42 percent today. Industry has also remained undeveloped offering employment to a more or less static 5 percent of the population. In the last two decades, productive sources of growth were squeezed out by an over-concentration of public sector spending on activities that did little to contribute to economic development, and in reality squandered the resources of the country and trapped the rural population in a chronic and deteriorating poverty spiral.
 Annex B Page 2 of 6 B. Main Elements of the Poverty Strategy 5. It can be seen from the above that an effective poverty reduction strategy needs to be constructed from a number of important elements. Firstly, with the end of the war, the return of economic and civilian stability, the main causes of transitory poverty have been eliminated, and conditions are favorable for actions to reverse the effects. The primary focus for action will be the implementation of well-targeted programs that respond to the special needs and conditions of various groups, aimed at helping these groups reintegrate with social support structures and providing them with the means to achieve economic self-reliance. In some cases, the programs need provide little more than access to credit or other resources, together with appropriate training and technical support. In other cases, such as disabled victims of war, longer term support structures may be needed. But wherever possible, the goal will be to assist both communities and individuals to reduce or eliminate dependence on continuing state support. Although fairly simple in conception, these programs are nevertheless expensive in terms of both resources and capacity in a country gradually recovering from economic stagnation, and facing huge social and economic rehabilitation costs. 6. The strategy to reduce chronic poverty requires a more complex combination of elements. As chronic poverty has its roots in an incapacity of the economy to meet the pressures of population growth, the overall strategy will focus on both expanding the economy and reducing the rate of population growth. Increased economic growth is at the heart of the Government's economic development strategy, and will provide the basic, long-term sustainable foundation for poverty reduction. Economic growth will not only provide an expansion of employment and incomes, but will also respond to chronic poverty in two other important ways. Firstly, it will reduce food insecurity, which is the most serious vulnerability for the chronically poor. This will be accomplished both through an increase in domestic food production, and through increased export earnings which can be used to pay food imports to cover any gaps in domestic production. Secondly, economic growth will increase government revenues at the same time as permitting increased devolution of economic responsibility from the public to the private sector. The result will be a higher allocation of public resources for the basic social services and infrastructure vital to improving the living conditions and economic prospects of the chronically poor. 7. Another important strategic element to reduce chronic poverty is the important poverty characteristics of the different regions of the country. Although there are no parts of Ethiopia that are free of significant poverty, there are some regions that were especially neglected, badly affected by war, or prone to natural disaster. Particularly in Wello, Tigray, Hararghe, and Gamgoffa, a large majority of households are classified as chronically poor or very vulnerable. These are areas suffering from significant degradation of environmental resources, rural isolation due to inadequacies of the road network, very poor social services and facilities, and limited economic options. Even in the most badly afflicted regions, there are both the resources and human potential for long-term development and reduction of poverty. However, unless these regions receive special attention, and the resource transfers to build the basic infrastructure for both productive activities and social service delivery, it is possible that they could be by-passed by the wider benefits of economic growth. It is also essential that regions are assisted in building the capacity to initiate and manage a development process relevant to their own specific needs, and that this process is linked as closely as possible to the grass-roots through community participation and ownership.

Based on the strategy described above, the Government's program of poverty reduction is diverse but with interlinked interventions, each of which are complex and described in detail in other documents, but which will be presented briefly here. 9. Targeted Assistance Programs. There are now a large range of special targeted assistance programs aimed at the needs of special groups who are suffering the consequences of war, policy neglect, or the transitory effects of economic reform. At a summary level the most important of these programs are: (a) Rehabilitation Programs for Returning Refugees, providing both consumption and production assistance to help 550,000 refugees from Somalia, Sudan, and Djibouti to reintegrate into urban and rural communities. (b) Program for Retrenched Public Sector Employees, which will provide retrenched persons with compensatory payments, training for redeployment, and credit for income- generating ventures. (c) Rehabilitation Programs for Ex-Soldiers, providing just under 500,000 ex-soldiers with both temporary food assistance and access to a revolving fund to purchase productive assets, to assist their reintegration into urban and rural life. (d) Consumption Assistance Program for Socially Disadvantaged Groups, responding to the needs of about 25,000 households made up of the elderly, disabled, and orphans. (e) Production Assistance for the Poorest of Poor Rural Households, providing cash assistance to about 160,000 poor rural households to purchase inputs such as fertilizer, seeds, handtools, and veterinary drugs. (f) Public Works Programs, which will be put into effect in 15 cities where the urban poor are concentrated, and which, in collaboration with local communities, will concentrate on agricultural and infrastructure assets that will reduce vulnerability to natural disasters and provide economic opportunities. These programs are supplemented by food/cash- for-work programs in areas such as soil conservation, irrigation, and dam construction. (g) Rehabilitation Assistance for Displaced People, providing essential agricultural inputs to assist over 150,000 displaced persons to take up farming activities in Tigray, Amhara, Oromiya, and Southern Ethiopia. Reducing Population Growth. While reducing population growth rate is a complex and long-term prospect, it is also an essential requirement for the utility of many of the other poverty reduction actions that will be taken. Unless the growth in population can be managed, the benefits of economic growth will not be effectively captured, the task of improving basic social service delivery will not be feasible, and the goal of sustainable environmental
 Annex B Page 4 of 6 conservation will become unattainable. Rapid population growth has not only placed basic services and natural resources under great strain, but also dramatically altered the demographic profile of the country increasing the proportion of unemployment among the young and wasting the productive resources of the nation. High fertility rates combined with high rates of infant mortality and infant disease places an inordinate strain on poor women and reduces their opportunity to play a productive role in economic activities. Managing population growth will become even more urgent as the improvements in primary health care result in lower mother and child mortality rates and an increase in life expectancy. 11. The Government has therefore adopted a population policy which has set goals for reductions in the current high rates of fertility from an average of 7.7 children per woman to an average of about 4 children per woman by 2015. This goal will be achieved through a combination of measures including a significant increase in contraceptive use; reductions in maternal, infant, and child mortality; increase in female educational enrollments, removal of legal and customary constraints on women's economic and social activities; and the launching of a nationwide population education and information program to promote the importance of smaller families, and the link between family size, human welfare, and environmental security. These approaches form the basis for a program which will be accompanied by improved research, data collection, analysis, and dissemination regarding population trends and issues. To design and implement this multi-disciplinary approach to population management, and to ensure the integration of mainstream population management initiatives with efforts to promote improved income-earning opportunities in the various productive sectors, a National Population Council has been established made up of a number of sector ministers and heads of relevant agencies, each of whose organizations will have specific implementation responsibilities in the population program. This national body will be supported by a structure of population councils at the regional and zonal levels, and committees at the woreda level. 12. Stimulating Economic Growth. Employment generating economic growth will be the most important foundation for long-term sustainable reduction of chronic poverty in Ethiopia. The program to stimulate economic growth has four key elements. The first is the maintenance of macro-economics stability through prudent fiscal and monetary management. Much has already been achieved in this respect, and it is the goal of this program to ensure that the budget deficit is carefully managed and progressively reduced, along with domestic bank financing of the deficit; that inflation is kept under control; that the foreign exchange rate is kept competitive based on market provision of foreign exchange; and that real positive interest rates are maintained to stimulate savings. The second is to stimulate production to generate employment, increase domestic production of food and other essential commodities, and increase exports. The Government has adopted a strategy of agricultural-development-led industrialization (ADLI), which responds to the current limitations of the agricultural sector and its key role in the economy. The goal of this policy is a parallel emphasis on three sources of growth and employment. The first is to increase output from the agriculture sector through improvement of productivity in small-holdings and expansion of large-scale farms, especially in the lowlands. The second is to significantly increase the productivity of the industrial and service sectors, in recognition of the limitations of the agricultural sector in providing employment for Ethiopia's rapidly increasing population. The third is to increase the production of minerals to add diversity to Ethiopia's exports. 13. The third key element in stimulating economic growth is to encourage investment by stimulating the growth of the private sector, streamlining licensing, export, and import processes,
 Annex B Page 5 of 6 rationalizing and divesting state enterprises, ensuring the availability of foreign exchange, and liberalizing the financial sector to provide a wider range of investment and international banking services. Finally, underpinning both the stimulation of production and encouragement of investment, the program to increase economic growth will require significant selective investment in infrastructure, services, and resource management. In terms of infrastructure the key priorities are road improvement and maintenance, and expansion of electricity supply. In terms of services, priorities include agricultural extension and research, and the provision of improved rural credit. Finally, expansion of agricultural production and an increase in mining activities will require emphasis on a number of aspects of environmental rehabilitation and conservation. 14. Provision of Improved Social Services. Another key aspect of the poverty reduction program is the expansion and improvement in quality of basic social services which will have a critical impact not only on the quality of life for the chronic poor, but also improve their access to economic opportunities and contribute to their productivity. The Government has made significant reallocations of budgetary resources for the social services, increasing spending since FY89 from 12 to 24 percent of the total budget. The largest proportion of these increases are going to basic services, primary education (which is now receiving 47 percent of the education budget), and primary rural health care (for which the allocation within the health budget has almost doubled since FY89). Within the education and health programs, emphasis will be given to a number of factors directly related to poverty reduction. In education this includes improving the participation of girls, improving female literacy, correcting regional imbalances, and improving the incentives for primary enrollments by utilizing local languages. Within the health sector, special emphasis is being given to expansion of maternal and child health, the control of communicable diseases, nutrition programs, and complementary measures to improve access to safe water and sanitation. 15. Focus on Regional and Community Development. The final important aspect of the poverty reduction process is the emphasis on regional and community development. As indicated earlier in this paper, while there are few parts of Ethiopia that do not suffer from chronic poverty, there is a concentration of especially poor and vulnerable households in certain regions of the country that have experienced extensive war destruction, the displacement of their populations, policy neglect, and climatic and environmental damage. Ethiopia has launched a far-reaching process of regional devolution, which will facilitate economic and social development and the reduction of chronic poverty. By taking responsibility for managing the development process, regional administrations can ensure that the special needs and conditions of the regions are taken into account in the development planning process. There are a number of ways in which this trend can contribute to poverty reduction: fostering the participation and ownership of communities (including community cost-sharing, appropriate cost recovery mechanisms, and improved community maintenance of assets); encouraging the use of labor-intensive methods, appropriate technologies, and local resources; and improving the efficiency of implementation by removing central bottlenecks, expanding technical and managerial capacity within the regions, and encouraging the growth of local private sector contractors. The Government has already ensured that regions with special rehabilitation and development needs receive the necessary resources, and has launched a far-reaching program to train officials and other facilitators of the development process. The next step will be to prepare in-depth regional development plans that respond both to the special needs and poverty profile of the regions, but also exploit the natural assets and resources the regions provide.
