The Ethiopian Social Rehabilitation and Development Fund (ESRDF) is an important component of the poverty reduction strategy and program described above. While the main focus of the ESRDF is to contribute to the reduction of chronic poverty, it will also be of benefit to special targeted groups, especially poor women. The special contribution of the ESRDF will take a number of forms. Firstly, the program is aimed at building community self-reliance by providing poor communities in rural areas with economic assets critical to improved incomes, social assets vital to improving the quality of life and productive potential, and knowledge, skills, and experience in managing their own development. Secondly, while the program will respond to any community initiative that is feasible, sustainable, and truly developmental, it will give special focus to sectors that have been identified as vital in the strategy to reduce chronic poverty: namely, rural water supply and conservation, small-scale irrigation, primary health facilities and services, basic education facilities and services, and micro-enterprise development through support for small-scale income-generation initiatives. In addition, by taking an activist role in promoting development practices among communities, the ESRDF can also make a positive impact on environmental practices, nutrition standards, family planning, energy savings, and a number of other interventions of great importance to poverty reduction. The ESRDF will also be an important method of piloting and experimenting with approaches to community-based development, helping to integrate sectoral interventions in mutually reinforcing ways. The program will also provide an opportunity to test new institutional mechanisms at a local level, especially the strengthening of traditional savings organizations and service cooperatives to provide micro-credit and small-scale banking services to communities currently beyond the reach of the financial sector Finally, the ESRDF will make an important contribution to building capacities and skills at the regional level, and in this way helping to strengthen the responsiveness of regional administrations to community-based participative development and the utilization of labor-intensive approaches. 17. The project to support the expanded ESRDF will contain a component to support the establishment of a poverty monitoring system for Ethiopia. This component will contribute an invaluable and indispensable tool for poverty reduction, enabling policy makers to track the impact on poverty levels of both broadly conceived economic reform measures, as well as specific targeted programs and interventions. The poverty monitoring system will be especially important in establishing a reliable information base on the sources and nature of poverty in different regions of the country, and provide the foundation for the design and monitoring of regional development programs with a poverty reduction focus.

 Annex G Page I of 2 Rural Water Supply Component I. Background. About 30 percent of ESRDF sub-project support will go to rural water supply schemes. In line with Government policy, these will require community contributions to capital costs, user fees to cover recurrent costs, and selection of simple and low cost technology manageable by communities. The RWS component complements the National Rural Water Supply Program (NRWSP) which finance larger schemes for bigger population centers. The Government's Sector Policy specifies that public agencies will act as promoters, regulators, and financial providers, with beneficiaries responsible for implementation, operation and maintenance. To support this devolution, both the ESRDF and the IDA-supported Ethiopia Water Supply Development & Rehabilitation Project (WSDRP) will contain substantial capacity building components. 2. Scope and Standards of the ESRDF RWS Sub-Projects. ESRDF will support small schemes involving hand-dug wells to supply up to 200 beneficiaries, and drilled wells with handpumps, and spring developments to serve up to 500 beneficiaries (based on a per capita water consumption of 15 to 20 liters a day). Technology selection will be based on factors like locally available water sources, cost considerations, community preferences and willingness to pay. The number of beneficiaries is a major factor. The ESRDF consulting with the Bank, can consider an untypical solution proposed by a community where the community can justify it in cost-benefit and social terms, and sustainability. In special situations, the ESRDF could finance options such as rainwater harvesting, sub-surface dams, and conventional piped schemes, but all of these will be subject to the same stringent appraisal standards. A community's willingness and capacity to make additional contributions to both project costs and recurrent expenses can also be taken into account. Efforts will also be made to exploit beneficial links between RWS sub-projects and other ESRDF initiatives, for example combining water supply for a school with facilities for community households. 3. Appraisal. ESRDF appraisal of a community RWS proposal will focus on (i) the seriousness of the water problem in the community, and the extent to which the proposed scheme can remedy it; (ii) the community's willingness and ability to contribute to both project and recurrent costs, and to maintain the scheme; (iii) the appropriateness of the community management structure for RWS, and the participation of women; (iv) technical capacity and training requirements for implementation and maintenance; (v) potential for self-sufficiency based on feasible user fees; and (vi) cost-efficiency of the proposed scheme compared to established investment and recurrent cost standards and other feasible options. The financial efficiency assessments will recognize the potential for the scheme to improve health and liberate women's time to be used more productively. To ensure that communities in sparsely populated areas are not excluded, appraisals will allow for initial capacity utilization of 50 percent of the maximum number of beneficiaries served by a particular technology, as long as the community is able to increase its contribution to capital and recurrent costs. 4. Implementation Structures. The communities will be responsible, through project committees, for managing implementation. The ESRDF will work in collaboration with the Ministry of Water Resources Development, and the Regional Water Development Bureaus to ensure that the ESRDF support meets the policy objectives and standards of the broader RWS program, and to test community-based approaches. Regional bureaus will provide technical advice to communities, and assist ESRDF in sub-project appraisal, and the supervision of schemes before and after completion, including testing water quality. Regional bureaus will need to be satisfied that the typical designs incorporated in the ESRDF technical RWS handbook are acceptable, and that sub-projects meet these standards before the sub-projects can be financed. 5. Maintenance. The regular maintenance of RWS schemes supported by the ESRDF will be largely self-financing through the collection of user fees. The financing contract signed with the

Training will be provided for community caretakers, and the WRD bureau will regularly inspect schemes to ensure they are being maintained.  Annex H Page I of 3 Small-Scale Irrigation Component 1. Objectives of Component. The objective of this component is to help poor farmers overcome rainfall and water constraints to production by providing a more assured supply of water for cultivation and livestock, and in this way contributing to strengthening the basis for subsistence agriculture, providing increased food security to poor communities, providing a source of household income through the sale of surplus production, and overall, assisting the increase in domestic food production. Especially in the northern Highlands area, irrigated agriculture will make an important contribution to improvement in very poor nutrition levels. The ESRDF will support sub-projects initiated by communities or farmer groups to develop small-scale irrigation schemes that are simple enough to be managed at the community level, and can help stabilize food production by supplementing crop moisture during shortfalls in rain and by supporting the cultivation of vegetables during the dry season. In the dry zones, the sub- projects will often involve the building of small storage dams which can be used both for irrigation and animal watering. Supplementary run-off wells can also be constructed to provide separate safe water for domestic use during extreme droughts. 2. General Description of the Component. Based on prior assessments of community needs, it is anticipated that community proposals would result in the development of 18,000 ha of irrigated land through ESRDF-financed sub-projects. On average, this would consist of small schemes of between 50 and 200 ha each, distributed throughout the Highlands. Because many of the potential sites for these schemes are situated on international waterways, the Government calculated the expected overall abstractions from each of these waterways and it was agreed with the Bank that these represent the total amounts that the Project will be able to finance. 3. Two main irrigation systems will be used: diversions from weirs on rivers with sufficient flow throughout the dry season; and storage dams where the river flow is insufficient to provide water to the fields. Given the higher cost of the schemes irrigated from storage dams, their areas would be small and situated mainly in the driest areas, in the Tekeze basin. 4. Technical Issues. As they are major structures, diversion weirs will be made of good standard masonry with well-arranged joints and high quality cement mortar. Their crest will be subject to strong erosive forces and may need to be constructed of quality reinforced concrete. Because of high rates of evaporation and high sediment transport, most of the reservoir dams will be no less than 10 to 15 meters high or with storage capacity no less than two million cubic meters, and care will be taken to ensure necessary safety features. This will require mechanical construction with carefully designed and zoned embankments. Spillways, customarily consisting of earth and rock, will be carefully monitored to avoid regressive erosion. For the outlet works, use will be made of pipes with upstream valves or within culverts. Works will be carried out by hand-labor, if safe and technically possible, especially for storage dams. 5. Many schemes are likely to make use of surface water because of their relative simplicity for community maintenance and low foreign exchange cost. However, appraisal will be concerned to justify costs, and where it is clear that the development of water sources by storage or diversion dam would be too costly or unsuitable in a specific situation, pilots will be run to test the viability of optional efficient modern methods, for example, in parts of the Highlands, the use of pipeline conveyance rather than canals, and pressure systems with small sprinklers or drip irrigation.

Special attention will be given to the identification of suitable catchments (given that it is often difficult to estimate run-offs from small catchments) to ensure that those selected are large enough to fill reservoirs but not so large as to require costly flood disposal. Equally important will be the estimation of the likely rate of siltation of reservoirs. The ESRDF will develop a research program to improve the accuracy of such estimates, and to monitor existing schemes to measure conveyance losses in main canals, and boulder transpiration, including the impact of these on diversion weirs. In addition, care will be taken to ensure that appropriate treatment of catchment areas takes place in the right sequence, prior to dam construction. 7. Critical Appraisal Issues. Small-scale schemes downstream of weirs or dams will be designed as an integral part of local peasant farming operations, and the appraisal of weirs and dams will pay close attention to the relationship between the investment cost and the number of hectares to be irrigated, the number of beneficiary farmers, the fertility and cultivation potential of the land in the areas to be irrigated, the crop options, and the likely yields and income from such crops. Careful consideration will also be given to recent and likely drought patterns and the continuing availability of water, as well as the capacity of community groups to maintain the schemes, and their ability to meet recurrent costs through income generated by the facilities. Appraisals will also include a catchment analysis to determine the impact of the sub-project on both upstream and downstream users. Each scheme will be carefully assessed in terms of its environmantal impact and the risk that environmental degradation could harm the sustainability of the scheme itself. Another important factor will be the safety of communities living downstream of construction in the face of possible construction failure and food. A systematic checklist of safety factors is included in the Operational Manual. Each appraisal will contain the necessary technical studies (topography, soil survey, hydrological assessments, and environmental assessment). 8. Structure for Implementation and Maintenance. Special community committees made up of the prime beneficiaries, will take responsibility for construction, organization, and supervision. The ESRDF will collaborate with the Regional Bureaus of Natural Resources (BNR) to support the implementation of this component, supplemented by assistance from the Bureaus of Agriculture in the training of farmers in field irrigation, and provision of advice to community water user associations. Technical studies associated with sub-project design and appraisal will be done by private sub-contractors or NGOs, although in areas where no local expertise exists, the BNR will provide support. Small local contractors will be invited to bid on construction works, and will be selected and supervised by the community committee. Following completion of the scheme, the community project committee will be formed into a Water Users' Association, responsible for the management and maintenance of the facilities, and collection of user contributions to the recurrent cost fund. The BNR will sign an agreement with the ESRDF and community associations to monitor maintenance and provide help where major repairs are beyond the capacity of the associations. 9. Capacity Building. Training and technical support will be an essential part of the component. The WMS will assist the Government to monitor the social impact of its economic reform program and their contribution to poverty reduction, helping decision-making and planning at both national and regional level. The WMS will be built around an Annual Review of Social Trends and Welfare reflecting changes in the status of different population groups, and identifying key policy issues for further consideration. The system will: (i) present a national and regional review of welfare indicators showing their spatial distribution and movements over time; (ii) identify poor and vulnerable groups that require targeted assistance; (iii) assess the short and medium term effects of macro-economic and sectoral policies and programs on the poor; and (iv) monitor changes in status of the poor and vulnerable population groups. 2. The WRC will meet not less that twice annually to review the policy implications of WMS reports and to approve the WMS annual work program. An Implementation Sub-Committee of the WRC will act as the WMS Steering Committee and will supervise implementation of the system.  Annex J Page I of 5 Environmental Assessment I. General. The Transitional Government of Ethiopia is committed to addressing environmental issues and in ensuring that economic growth in the future will be sustainable. Since 1990, a process has been underway to develop a National Conservation Strategy (NCS), which is the Ethiopian Government's equivalent to a National Environmental Action Plan. The NCS, which articulates a set of policies. strategies, actions and investment programs to address the main environmental and development issues currently prevailing in the country, is shortly to be approved by the Council of Ministers. Eventually, each regional Government will be expected to formulate regional conservation strategies based on the guiding principles and framework of the National Conservation Strategy. The NCS is comprehensive in scope, highlighting a range of issues across several sectors including land degradation and loss of tree cover, insufficient supply and poor quality of water resources, urban degradation, progressive loss of bio-diversity and inappropriate rangeland management. It is within the context of this overall strategy that the Government aims to pursue two important environmental objectives under the ESRDF project. The first is to ensure that each sub-project approved for funding, will have been reviewed for potential negative environmental impacts and that appropriate mitigating measures will have been taken for any impacts identified. Projects which are found to have negative environmental impacts which cannot be adequately mitigated will not be approved for funding. The second is to use the project as a vehicle for proactively pursuing the Government's environmental objectives through promoting better environmental practices and increasing the positive environmental impact of sub-projects. 2. Environmental Effects of Sub-Projects. In most cases the negative environmental impact of the individual sub-projects is expected to be localized and limited. Table I lists the main categories of projects identified by the Government as those most likely to be requested by communities. Column two of the table briefly highlights the potential negative effects of each category of project with column three specifying the mitigating measures that may be necessary to overcome these effects. The only potential area of concern relates to small-scale irrigation sub-projects. Here, necessary actions will be incorporated at the design stage. For example, attention will need to be paid to ensure that adequate soil conservation measures are undertaken in the case of micro-dam construction to stem the effects of high levels of siltation, a common problem throughout most of Ethiopia. Adequate extension support to farmers in the proper use of irrigated land will also be important not only to enhance the quality of the project's impact on agricultural productivity, but also to prevent more serious problems of water logging and salinization of the soils. Awareness of prevailing land use patterns will also be important. Care will need to be taken to ensure that irrigation schemes do not displace local populations who might be using the area for grazing or rain fed farming, that the schemes do not damage the access to water of downstream communities, and that appropriate measures are taken to prevent an increased incidence of water borne or water-related diseases as a result of the new dams or irrigation channels. 3. The remaining categories of sub-projects to be funded under ESRDF are expected to have relatively minor negative environmental impacts, though these will still need to be taken seriously. For instance, poorly managed water supply or sanitation schemes can sometimes create greater health hazards than those that they were originally designed to address. Health and education centers, if constructed with wood can contribute to the depletion of forest resources in the local neighborhood. Medical wastes can also generate a health hazard if they are not properly disposed of. Micro-enterprises and other income-generating activities can make
 Annex J Page 2 of 5 unsustainable demands on local wood or water supplies if improperly designed. All these potential impacts can be identified during appraisal process and addressed in project design. For instance, alternative construction materials to wood could be found. Incinerators for the proper disposal of waste materials could be constructed at health center sites. Measures to ensure proper drainage and protection around a water source could be enforced etc. 4. Building Capacity. The key to ensuring that appropriate measures to safeguard against negative environmental impacts under the project is to ensure that the ESRDF staff have the capacity to adequately screen, oversee the design of sub-projects and monitor their implementation in accordance with environment criteria. The present capacity of ESRDF to undertake any of these functions is weak. In order to meet its environmental objectives, ESRDF will need to devote substantial effort and resources to building up the capacity of the ESRDF staff to carry out its environmental work. 5. There are three main ways in which this capacity will be strengthened. First of all the process by which sub-projects are screened, appraised and approved, will be designed in such as way that potential negative environmental impacts can be identified at an early stage and adequate mitigating measures incorporated into the project design in consultation with the community/ies concerned. To this end the ESRDF Operational Manual has been designed to include an environmental checklist for each of the main categories of project that are likely to be requested by communities. Where potential problems are identified, ESRDF staff will review what kind of mitigating measures might be appropriate and who will be responsible for implementing these. ESRDF will then be responsible for ensuring that these measures are adhered to in the design and implementation of the project by the communities concerned and their contractees. Close attention will be paid to modifying or updating the checklists once the ESRDF staff have had a chance to apply them in practice. 6. The second way in which ESRDF capacity will be enhanced, is by ensuring appropriately skilled staff in ESRDF. Given that environmental issues are generally closely interwoven with sectoral concerns, the appointment of additional staff to deal specifically with environmental issues will be avoided as far as possible. Rather, the aim will be to train individual sector specialists to integrate appropriate environmental approaches into their mainstream activities. To oversee the ESRDF's environmental activities and capacity building efforts, a broad based technical environmental specialist will be appointed at the Central Office to act as a catalyst for all issues of environmental concern under the project. This person will have overall responsibility for providing technical support and back-up to regional offices, organize training, review and update the sections of the operational manual relating to environmental appraisal and assessment and ensuring that the project's environmental objectives are being achieved. 7. At the regional level, one existing staff (not necessarily an environmental specialist) will be designated as environmental focal point with responsibility for overseeing and coordinating the implementation of the ESRDF's environmental agenda at the regional level. It is anticipated that there will be times when additional specific expertise will be required, for instance if there is a need for a more in-depth environmental assessment of a sub-project or to draw up environmental check-lists for new categories of projects not already covered by the operational manual. In such cases the project will draw on locally available expertise on a consultancy basis. A roster of suitably qualified environmental specialists will be drawn up by the project at an early stage.
 Annex J Page 3 of 5 8. The third way in which environmental capacity will be strengthened, is through providing ESRDF staff, particularly at the regional level, with increased awareness of environmental issues related to the community based activities implemented under the project, and with the skills to appraise sub-projects for their possible environmental effect. In addition to training ESRDF staff, the project will also provide technical training to selected Government staff and other stakeholders. This training would be aimed at providing the skills to integrate environmental concerns into sub-project design, and for ensuring that activities under the sub- projects will be environmentally sustainable. Specific training modules for this purpose will be devised and included as part of more general technical training that will be implemented under the ESRDF project. In certain cases training of selective groups of government development agents will also be undertaken to enhance their skills in training project beneficiaries to make sub-project activities environmentally sustainable (e.g. appropriate soil and water conservation practices in connection with small-scale irrigation projects). 9. Promoting the Government's Environmental Objectives. One important way in which the Government plans to promote its environmental agenda is to incorporate environmental perspectives in the ESRDF's community promotion activities. The purpose will be to inform communities of possible means of addressing some of their more serious environmental problems such as land degradation (including gulleying), loss of tree cover and lack of water for agricultural or domestic purposes. Care will be taken not to impose solutions on communities, but rather to present them with a range of options and inform them of what other communities have already tried and their successes. In addition to encouraging specific 'environment' sub-projects, ESRDF will also make efforts to encourage environmentally positive components to be built into the various categories of sub-projects. For instance, the use of renewable energy such as solar panels, will be explored as a source of energy for health clinics or for micro-enterprises requiring power, rather than resorting to fuel wood. Tree planting will be encouraged in the vicinity of schools and health clinics funded under the project. Water harvesting in the form of roof catchments will be encouraged as part of the design of school buildings or health facilities. These and similar components will be based on natural community incentives as well as best local practices observed by the ESRDF in its field work with communities. 10. Monitoring. The performance of ESRDF in ensuring that environmental concerns are appropriately incorporated into the project will be closely monitored particularly during the first year of project implementation. ESRDF environmental coordinator in the Central Office will have primary responsibility for maintaining regular contact with regional staff, obtaining feed- back from them on the fulfillment of their environmental functions and modifying procedures in accordance with feed-back and recommendations from project staff. A thorough review of the process of integrating environmental concerns into project activities will be undertaken at the end of the first year. In addition, environmental indicators have been incorporated into the project MIS and evaluation systems so that the ESRDF can keep track of whether the appraisal process is indeed resulting in environmentally sound projects. Each major report on ESRDF performance will contain chapters on its environmental activities and their achievements.

The "National Policy on Ethiopian Women" highlights that although women actively participate in all walks of life, they do not usually benefit from their labor and are not given an equal chance to compete with men. The majority work in the informal economic sectors and the average rural women's work day, with regional and cultural variations, is between 13 to 17 hours, with very low income. Land is normally registered to the male head of the household and excludes women. The Policy adds that women spend on an average 5 hours collecting fuel wood for cooking and carry 28 kilos of wood. Water is carried at least twice a day, on average over a distance of 3 to 5 km. Only 5 percent of all women are assisted by trained mid-wives. The maternal mortality rate is one of the highest in the developing world, at 20 per 1000 live births. Each year, 17,000 women die if child bearing complications. Ethiopia also has a very high fertility rate of 7.5 children per woman. Ninety-eight percent of Ethiopian women have no access to family planning services. The Policy also acknowledges that existing legislation assists in perpetuating a secondary socio-economic status for women. 2. The Policy encourages the integration of gender issues in the overall development program of the country to enhance the participation of women, to make them equal beneficiaries of development programs, and to safeguard their right and equal access to land and property. 3. In keeping with the stated objectives of the National Policy, the ESRDF has developed a Gender Action Plan (GAP) to address gender issues in sub-projects financed by the Fund. GAP has been designed to reinforce the demand-driven approach of the Fund and is summarized in the attachment. The key elements of GAP include: (i) special promotional activity to encourage communities to plan and design projects focusing on women's priorities and needs; (ii) incorporation of measures in all existing processes in a sub-project cycle to ensure identification of any adverse gender impact; (iii) development of indicators to prioritize the selection of sub- projects addressing priorities and needs of women; (iv) encouragement to include nutritional activities that focus on the needs of women and children; (v) encouraging the design of income- generating activities for women, coupled with savings schemes; (vi) involving NGOs specialized in women's development to assist ESRDF implementation in ways that benefit women; (vii) incorporation into training activities, attention to the socio-economic constraints women face, and opportunities for their advancement; (viii) inclusion of gender indicators in the project MIS and reporting system; and (ix) inclusion of a specialized staff member in the ESRDF Central Office to take charge of coordinating women's activities, imparting gender sensitivity training to all staff of the Fund, and monitoring the impact of ESRDF activities on women. doc.repnme: Ethiopia - Ethiopian Social Rehabilitation and Development Fund Project
doc.abstracts: The Ethiopian Social Rehabilitation and Development Fund Project (ESRDF) will provide to poor, mainly rural communities the assets and services needed to improve their economic and social standards. ESRDF will provide financial and technical support to communities and community groups to construct or rehabilitate, and maintain basic economic and social infrastructure and services that they have prioritized and in which they are willing to invest. In addition, ESRDF will support community actions aimed at environmental conservation and rehabilitation. ESRDF's efforts will be focused on poor communities, and especially, poor women. To achieve these goals, ESRDF will strengthen community capacity in project identification, implementation, and maintenance. The project will also support the establishment of a Welfare Monitoring System to strengthen capacity to collect and analyze information related to causes, patterns, and incidence of poverty; and improve the basis for developing poverty reduction strategies, assessing the impact on the poor of economic policy reform, and evaluating the benefits of other poverty reductions interventions. The components of this project will be as follows: 1) construction and rehabilitation of social and economic infrastructure and improvement of related services including basic health and education, small-scale irrigation, urban sanitation and rural water supply; 2) welfare monitoring system; and 3) capacity building, training and research.
